#  Welcome

This is a relatively compact and short introduction to evaluation models.

---

# The Basics 

```{r echo=FALSE}
basics <- tibble(
  
  name = c(
    "Behavioral Objectives Approach",
    "The Four-Level Model",
    "Responsive Evaluation",
    "Goal-Free Evaluation"
  ),
  
  desc = c("the degree to which the objectives of a program, product, or process have been achieved.",
           "four levels of training outcomes: reactions, learning, behavior, and results.",
           "evaluators need to be responsive to the information needs of various audiences or stakeholders.",
           "the actual outcomes rather than the intended outcomes of a program so the evaluator has minimal contact with the program managers and staff and is unaware of the programâ€™s stated goals and objectives."
  ),

asks = c("<i>is the program, product, or process achieving its objectives?</i>",
         "<i>what impact did the training have on participants in terms of their reactions, learning, behavior, and organizational results?</i>",
         "<i>what does the program look like to different people?</i>",
         "<i>what are all the effects of the program, including any side effects?</i>"
         )

)
```

# The Drivers

```{r echo=FALSE}
driver <- tibble(
  
  name = c(
    "Theory Driven Evaluation",
    "Utilization Focused Evaluation",
    "Participatory Evaluation",
    "Empowerment Evaluation"
  ),
  
  desc = c("theoretical rather than methodological issues bydeveloping a plausible
model of how the program is supposed to work.",
           "done for and with specific, intended primary users for specific, intended uses and assumes that stakeholders will have a high degree of involvement in many, if
not all, phases of the evaluation.",
           "engaging stakeholders in the evaluation process, so they may better understand evaluation and the program being evaluated and ultimately use the evaluation findings for decision-making purposes.",
           "use of evaluation concepts, techniques, and findings to foster improvement and self-determination."
           ),
  
  asks = c("<i>how is the program supposed to work? what are the assumptions underlying the programâ€™s development and implementation?</i>",
           "<i>What are the information needs of stakeholders, and how will they use the findings?</i>",
           "<i>what are the information needs of those closest to the program?</i>",
           "<i>what are the information needs to foster improvement and self-determination?</i>"
         )
)
```

# Which One to Use?

You don't have to formally declare a model. In fact, unless specific circumstances demand it, its better that you probably don't. Recently there has been a push to get away from a design oriented evaluation approach which is good for many reasons - for one you aren't pigeonholing yourself to a predetermined structure that 

1. may not apply exactly resulting in skewed results, and

2. dilutes or suppresses creativity and thinking. 

This allows you to deal with the program as is rather than viewing it through framework of a model. The bottom line is if we believe that *no two programs are alike, then why should we use a one size fit all approach to study it?*

---

# So should you care? 

Yes because even though a prior framework is likely not the best tool to use, you'll use parts of multiple models here and there. So rather than treating these as musts, think of them as possible approaches that can be combined, expanded, ignored, etc. Like anything else, they can help but most evaluations should never rely on any one of them.

---

# And That's It

Remember that models don't determine the course of an evaluation - you do! Use your best judgment, common sense, content knowledge, expertise, etc - the things that hopefully distinguish you both professionally and academically to administer a study. If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out.
